properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 29 at 3:13PM CDT until June 29 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Wichita KS
properties.description:
* Heat Index Values...Up to 105.

* Timing...Highest heat indices are expected between 5 PM and 7
PM.

* Impacts...Heat related injury for those engaged in strenuous
outdoor activities this afternoon and early evening.
properties.instruction:
Temperatures within vehicles can become lethal in a few minutes.
Never leave children or pets in vehicles. Remember to beat the
heat, check the backseat.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and
Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks
in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by
heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.  Heat stroke
is an emergency...CALL 9 1 1.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 29 at 3:12PM CDT until July 1 at 5:33AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
properties.description:
The flood warning continues for the Zumbro River at Zumbro falls.
The river has crested and will continue falling.

River forecasts take into account both observed and forecast
precipitation.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Zumbro River at Zumbro Falls.
* until late Sunday night...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 2:30 PM Saturday the stage was 26.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 18.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall...Dropping below flood
stage by Sunday morning.
* Impact...At 26.0 feet...Residential flooding may begin in Zumbro
Falls.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued June 29 at 3:53PM EDT until July 1 at 4:00AM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
Winds and seas are expected to increase Sunday afternoon ahead of
an approaching cold front. Wind gusts of 25-30 knots are expected
across the coastal waters south of Oregon Inlet and the Pamlico
Sound. Seas will build to 6 feet Sunday evening across the coastal
waters, diminishing overnight into Monday.
The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued
a Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 4 PM Sunday to
4 AM EDT Monday.

* WINDS...Southwest 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* SEAS...4 to 6 feet.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4 PM SUNDAY TO 4 AM EDT MONDAY

properties.instruction:

inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 10 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now! Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 29 at 11:42AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
properties.description:
Rivers and small streams in the Western Alaska Range will be on
the rise late Sunday and Monday.

A front moving into the interior on Sunday afternoon will bring
the potential for heavy rain to the Western Alaska Range including
Denali Park. Rain is expected to begin late Sunday afternoon and
will continue into Monday afternoon. Up to one and a half inches
of rain is expected through Monday afternoon with the heaviest
rain falling Sunday evening.

Travelers in the Alaska Range should be alert for heavy rainfall
and the possibility of high water and mudslides in steep terrain
Sunday and Monday.

NWSheadline: Significant Rain Expected in the Alaska Range Sunday and Monday

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 29 at 3:29PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
properties.description:
At 329 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
Zebulon, or 13 miles east of Raleigh, moving southeast at 15 mph.

Wind gusts up to 50 mph will be possible with this storm.

Heavy rain and minor flooding and deadly cloud to ground lightning
will also be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Zebulon, Bailey, Knightdale, Micro, Wendell, Middlesex, Sims, Emit,
Buckhorn Reservoir and Flowers.
properties.instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.

Cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.
Lightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Grand Junction has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Snowmelt in...
Southeastern La Plata County in southwestern Colorado...

* Until 115 PM MDT Thursday.

* An increase in flows along the Los Pinos River in eastern LaPlata
County can be expected as inflow above releases below Vallecito
Dam are increased. Elevated runoff above the dam is occurring as
warm temperatures have accelerated the melting of the ample high
elevation snowpack. These warm temperatures and possible rainfall
will keep runoff high into next week.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from snow melt has caused the Los Pinos and it's
tributaries to rise. Minor flooding along the banks of these
waterways and in low lying areas will be possible through early next
week.

properties.headline: Dense Smoke Advisory issued June 29 at 11:08AM AKDT until June 30 at 5:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage, AK
properties.description:
* LOCATION...Interior Kenai Peninsula including Seward.

* SMOKE...Dense smoke from the Swan Lake fire has drifted
southeastward across the interior Kenai Peninsula.
Visibilities may be reduced to one quarter mile or less at
times.

* TIMING...Through tonight, though there is potential for dense
smoke to persist all the way through the weekend.

* IMPACTS...Travel may be difficult due to low visibility.
Persons with respiratory problems may have difficulty
breathing when outside.
properties.instruction:
A dense smoke advisory means widespread fires will create smoke,
limiting visibilities. If driving,  Slow down, use your
headlights, and leave plenty of distance ahead of you in case a
sudden stop is needed. For the latest road conditions call
5 1 1 or visit 511.alaska.gov.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 29 at 1:52PM CDT until June 30 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI

Spillville today.  The river is expected to crest this evening.

precipitation.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


If you live in a threatened area, be alert for high or rising water,
and be ready to move to higher ground if necessary.

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Stay tuned to your favorite source of weather information, including
NOAA Weather Radio, for later statements.

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 29 at 1:49PM CDT until June 29 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
properties.description:
* TEMPERATURE...High temperatures in the low to mid 90s, with
heat index values of 100 to 105.

* TIMING...This afternoon and early evening.

* IMPACTS...The heat and humidity may cause heat stress during
outdoor exertion or extended exposure.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of hot temperatures and high humidity
will combine to create a situation in which heat illnesses are
possible. Drink plenty of fluids...stay in an air-conditioned

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 29 at 2:47PM EDT until July 3 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
Wabash River...White River...


.Flooding continues in southwestern Indiana from our recent rainy
weather. Some areas have seen rainfall amounts in excess of 10
inches this month.

Moderate flooding as of late Friday was confined to the Wabash River
from Mount Carmel downstream. Minor flooding continued on the White
River at Petersburg and Hazleton. Flooding is expected to conclude
by late in the day July 2.

Little to no rainfall is expected through July 3, thus rivers will
continue to recede.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Mount Carmel.
* until late Tuesday night.
* At 12:45 PM Saturday the stage was 25.1 feet.
* Flood stage is 19.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will continue to fall to below flood stage by Tuesday
morning.
* At 25.5 feet...Extensive lowland flooding in progress.  Much of the
flood plain activity is affected by high water.  Numerous local
river roads flood.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 29 at 1:45PM CDT until June 29 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Kansas City/Pleasant HIll MO
properties.description:
* TEMPERATURE...Afternoon temperatures will climb into the low
to middle 90s with oppressive humidity leading to heat index
values of 100 and 105.

* IMPACTS...Heat illness is possible for those spending
prolonged time outside or those who are more susceptible to
heat, such as young children and elderly.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of hot temperatures and high humidity
will combine to create a situation in which heat illnesses are
possible. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned
room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and
neighbors.

Take extra precautions, if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work, the occupational safety and
health administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks
in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by
heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.   Heat stroke
is an emergency, call 9 1 1.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM CDT THIS EVENING

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 29 at 1:44PM CDT by NWS Lincoln IL
properties.description:
..Hot and Humid Conditions This Afternoon and Early Evening...

Temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s across central
Illinois, combined with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s will
produce heat indices ranging from 97 to 102 degrees through 7 pm.

Exercise caution if you will be outdoors this afternoon and
early evening. Be sure to apply sunscreen regularly. Drink plenty
of water, dress in lightweight and light-color clothing, and take
breaks in the shade. Check on relatives and neighbors, especially
the elderly.

Never leave pets, children or the elderly unattended in parked
vehicles.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 29 at 9:44AM AKDT until July 1 at 9:45AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Anchorage has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Snowmelt in...

Yentna River near Fish Creek...

* Until 945 AM AKDT Monday.

Snow and glacial melt in the Yentna Basin have caused river levels
along the lower Yentna River to rise above Minor Flood Stage. Low
lying areas are expected to be flooded. River levels are expected to
remain in Minor Flood conditions until July 4. Flooding will remain
over mainly rural areas of central Susitna Valley.

of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 29 at 12:14PM CDT until June 29 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN
properties.description:
* TEMPERATURE...the combination of hot temperatures and high
humidity will combine to create heat indices this afternoon
around 100 degrees.

* IMPACTS...These heat indices during the day will lead to
increased risk for heat related illnesses for those active
outdoors or with limited access to air conditioned spaces.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of hot temperatures and high humidity
will combine to create a situation in which heat illnesses are
possible. Drink plenty of fluids...stay in an air-conditioned
room...stay out of the sun...and check up on relatives and
neighbors.

Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke.
Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when possible and
drink plenty of water.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM CDT THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Ramsey; Hennepin; Scott; Dakota; Washington; Carver; Anoka
properties.headline: Excessive Heat Warning issued June 29 at 12:14PM CDT until June 30 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN
properties.description:
* TEMPERATURE...Afternoon heat indices today and Sunday afternoon
are expected to top out around 100 degrees, with overnight lows
Sunday morning only falling to around 75 degrees.

* IMPACTS...These warm temperatures during the day, with limited
cooling overnight Saturday night will lead to increased risk
for heat related illnesses for those active outdoors or with
limited access to air conditioned spaces.
properties.instruction:
Take extra precautions...if you work or spend time outside. When
possible...reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

An Excessive Heat Warning means that a prolonged period of
dangerously hot temperatures will occur. The combination of hot
temperatures and high humidity will combine to create a dangerous
situation in which heat illnesses are likely. Drink plenty of
fluids...stay in an air-conditioned room...stay out of the sun...
and check up on relatives and neighbors.

NWSheadline: EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM CDT SUNDAY

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 29 at 12:12PM CDT until June 29 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
properties.description:
* HEAT INDEX VALUES...100 to 107 due to temperatures in the 90s
and dewpoints in the 70s.

* TIMING...Through this evening.

* IMPACTS...The heat and humidity may cause heat stress during
outdoor exertion or extended exposure.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of hot temperatures and high humidity
will combine to create a situation in which heat illnesses are
possible. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned
room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and
neighbors.

Take extra precautions, if you work or spend time outside. When
possible, reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

properties.headline: Excessive Heat Warning issued June 29 at 11:59AM CDT until June 29 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Sioux Falls SD
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Sioux Falls has issued an
Excessive Heat Warning, which is in effect until 9 PM CDT this
evening. The Heat Advisory is no longer in effect.

* HEAT INDEX VALUES...105 to 110, due to temperatures in the
mid to upper 90s, and dewpoints in the mid to upper 70s.

* TIMING...This afternoon and early evening.

* IMPACTS...The heat and humidity may cause heat stress during
outdoor exertion or extended exposure.
properties.instruction:
Take extra precautions...if you work or spend time outside. When
possible...reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when
possible and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work...the occupational safety
and health administration recommends scheduling frequent rest
breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome
by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.   Heat
stroke is an emergency...call 9 1 1.

An Excessive Heat Warning means that a prolonged period of
dangerously hot temperatures will occur. The combination of hot
temperatures and high humidity will combine to create a dangerous
situation in which heat illnesses are likely. Drink plenty of
fluids...stay in an air-conditioned room...stay out of the sun...
and check up on relatives and neighbors.

Young children and pets should never be left unattended in
vehicles under any circumstances.  This is especially true during
warm or hot weather when car interiors can reach lethal
temperatures in a matter of minutes.

NWSheadline: EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM CDT THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Pointe Coupee, LA; East Baton Rouge, LA; West Feliciana, LA
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 29 at 11:22AM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
properties.description:
Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes

Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Saturday the stage was 59.4 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain steady near 59.4 feet for at least
the next week.
* Impact...At 59.0 feet...The east bank levee will be topped and the
prison farm land between the two levees will be inundated. Angola
Landing will be under water closing the ferry there. All river
islands along the reach from Red River Landing to Baton Rouge will
remain inundated with recreational camps and river bottom farm land
under water.
* Impact...At 58.0 feet...Angola farmland on the left bank becomes
inundated.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 48 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued June 29 at 10:40AM CDT until June 29 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
properties.description:
* Heat Index Values...Up to 105 due to temperatures in the mid to
upper 90s...and dewpoints in the mid 60s to lower 70s.

* Timing...Peak heat index readings are expected between 3 and 6
PM.

* Impacts...Prolonged exposure to this heat can be dangerous if
the proper precautions are not taken.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of hot temperatures and high humidity
will combine to create a situation in which heat illnesses are
possible. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned
room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and
neighbors.

and stream information is available at www.weather.gov/kc/.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 29 at 4:40AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
properties.description:
The combination of very warm temperatures and high humidity will
lead to afternoon heat index readings of 90 to 100 degrees today,
and 95 to 105 degrees on Sunday. Readings this high can result in
heat-related illness developing in as little as 30 minutes. If you
will be outdoors working or enjoying recreation this weekend, be
sure to take frequent breaks and stay hydrated. Ensure that pets
also have access to fresh water and cool shelter, and check on
relatives and neighbors, especially those who are elderly.

NWSheadline: Hot and Humid Conditions for the Weekend

and dewpoints in the mid 60s.

stroke.

conditions. Take extra precautions if you work or spend time
outside.

* Flood Advisory for...
Snowmelt in...
North central Pershing County in west central Nevada...

* Until 1130 AM PDT Thursday.

* At 200 PM PDT Friday, June 28, minor flooding was occurring along
the Humboldt River above Rye Patch Reservoir.

* Forecast...Minor flooding will continue through much of next week,
with the river falling slowly. Minor flooding may continue into
mid-July.

farmland, and other low lying spots.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued June 28 at 1:20PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
properties.description:
Missouri River near Williston affecting McKenzie and Williams
Counties
For the Missouri River Basin including Williston...Minor flooding is
occurring...With Moderate flooding forecast.

. The up and down pattern for the Missouri River near Williston will
continue into July even as the longer trend will be for lower water
levels. However, the Missouri River near Williston will remain above
flood stage until at least the middle, if not latter part of July.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River near Williston.
* until further notice.
* At 12:45 PM Friday the stage was 23.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 24.4 feet by
Tuesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Water begins to cover oil well location
south and east of Williston. Wildlife management areas are flooded.
City of Williston does not flood.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...Do not drive into areas where water tops the
roadway. Turn around...Don't drown. Avoid driving on flooded roads.

properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued June 28 at 8:45AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
properties.description:
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality in Phoenix has issued
an Ozone High Pollution Advisory for the Greater Phoenix Area through
Saturday.

This means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing
ozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone
concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects
increase as air quality deteriorates.

Ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties
for children as well as persons with respiratory problems. A decrease
in physical activity is recommended.

If it is a regularly scheduled work day, you are urged to car pool,
telecommute or use mass transit.

The use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late
in the day.

For details on this High Pollution Advisory for Maricopa County,
visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov or call 602-771-2300.

NWSheadline: HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR MARICOPA COUNTY INCLUDING THE GREATER PHOENIX AREA THROUGH SATURDAY

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued June 26 at 1:58PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
properties.description:
PRZ005-006-252015-
Centro Interior-Ponce y Vecindad-
258 PM AST miercoles 26 de junio de 2019

...UNA TRONADA FUERTE AFECTARA LOS MUNICIPIOS DE VILLALBA...PONCE Y
JUANA DIAZ...

A las 255 PM AST, una tronada fuerte estaba localizada sobre
Villalba y el norte de Juan Diaz. Esta tronada esta moviendose
lentamente hacia el oeste.

Vientos en exceso de 30 mph son posibles con esta tronada. Lluvias
torrenciales tambien estan ocurriendo con esta tronada y pudieran
causar inundaciones localizadas. No maneje su vehiculo en areas
inundadas.

Rayos frecuentes de nube a suelo estan ocurriendo con esta tronada.
Los rayos pueden impactar hasta 10 millas de la tronada. Busque
refugio dentro de un edificio o vehiculo.
